title: Kashkari Says Fed Can't Let Up on Policy Action; CBO Offers Hope for GDP Rebound; RBA Extends QE Program
text:
Top News

Minneapolis Fed Chief: Federal Reserve Shouldn't Pull Back on Aid

The U.S. economy has a long way to go before it fully recovers and will need strong support from the Federal Reserve and the broader government to get there, Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis President Neel Kashkari said Monday. Mr. Kashkari also said it is critical that fiscal aid be in the mix as well, adding the central bank will use all available tools to help achieve its job and inflation goals.

Reserve Bank of Australia Extends QE Program Amid Recovery

Reserve Bank of Australia Gov. Philip Lowe said the central bank's current 100 billion Australian dollar, or roughly $76.22 billion, quantitative-easing program would be extended by a further A$100 billion after its expiry in April.

Glynn's Take: RBA Applies Maximum Pressure on Australian Dollar

By James Glynn

The Australian currency has climbed 6% on a trade-weighted basis since the start of 2020, fueled by surging iron ore prices. Any hint now that the RBA is preparing to step back from QE would have fueled the rally, slamming export prices and potentially snuffing out the country's economic recovery. Read More.

Key Developments Around the World

U.S. Economy Expected to Reach Pre-Pandemic Peak by Mid-2021

The Congressional Budget Office said it expects gross domestic product will return to its pre-pandemic level by the middle of this year, thanks in part to a surge of relief spending Congress authorized in 2020, including aid for households and businesses.

* Republicans Propose $618 Billion Covid-19 Stimulus Plan

Indian Budget Promises More Spending to Recover From Recession

India's Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman on Monday unveiled ambitious spending plans in the country's budget for the year starting April. Increased spending on roads, education, hospitals and other infrastructure is necessary to bring the country back to high growth, she said.

Financial Regulation Roundup

New York Bank Fined For Anti-Money-Laundering Law Failures

Apple Bank for Savings agreed to pay $12.5 million to settle a regulator's claims that it allegedly violated the Bank Secrecy Act, an anti-money-laundering law, between April 2014 and September 2018, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said.

Former JPMorgan Banker Acquitted in Bribery Trial

Catherine Leung Kar-cheung, a former vice chairwoman of JPMorgan Chase's Asia-Pacific investment banking business, was acquitted of bribing a potential client by hiring his son, in a defeat for Hong Kong's antigraft agency.

Risky Borrowers Hope to Boost Green Credentials

Investors' thirst for yield in debt markets is driving demand for the risky loans that fund private equity deals. That is allowing companies to begin testing new features designed to boost their green and governance credentials.

Research

Fiscal Aid More Powerful When Fed Has Rates Near Zero

With interest rates as low as they are, most of the burden in government efforts to help the economy overcome the effects of the coronavirus pandemic should be on fiscal policy, Federal Reserve Bank of Boston leader Eric Rosengren said Monday. New research from the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco backs up his view. "Research suggests that expanding government spending is not very effective at stimulating an economy in normal times," Regis Barnichon, Davide Debortoli and Christian Matthes wrote in a paper made public by the bank Monday. "However, in deep downturns when monetary policy is constrained at the zero lower bound, public spending is more potent and can become an effective way to escape a recession."

Commentary

Stimulus Debate Tests Limits of Democrats' Election Mandate

President Biden and his Democratic Party face a big decision this week, on whether to push into law a larger coronavirus stimulus bill on their own, or a smaller one with some Republican support, Gerald F. Seib writes.

Basis Points

* U.S. manufacturing continued to recover in January. The Institute for Supply Management 's manufacturing index ticked lower to 58.7 from 60.5, remaining in growth mode. The final January IHS Markit manufacturing survey rose to 59.2 from 57.1 in December.

* U.S. construction spending rose 1% in December at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $1.49 trillion after a revised 1.1% gain in November, the Commerce Department said. (Dow Jones Newswires)

* Eurozone GDP fell by 0.7% in the fourth quarter, according to statistics agency Eurostat 's first estimate. Economists polled by WSJ had expected a 1.2% contraction. (DJN)

* The eurozone's jobless rate remained at 8.3% in December, even as a sharp rise in new coronavirus infections and tightened government restrictions led many businesses to reduce or suspend their services, the European Union 's statistics agency said. (DJN)

* The upturn in U.K. manufacturing slowed at the start of 2021 as export orders were hit by stretched supply chains due to Brexit and Covid-19 restrictions. IHS Markit 's January's manufacturing PMI stood at 54.1, down from 57.5 in December. (DJN)

* South Korea's headline consumer inflation accelerated by 0.6% year-over-year in January, well below the central bank's 2% target. The Bank of Korea expects inflation to average 1.0% in 2021 and 1.5% in 2022. (DJN)
